clinical_study.brief_title: Influence of Stress and Psychiatric Symptoms on Children With Tourette Syndrome
clinical_study.official_title: Influence of Stress and Psychiatric Symptoms on Children With Tourette Syndrome

brief_summary.textblock: Investigators propose a cross-sectional, observational pilot study to explore the prevalence of stress among adolescents with Tourette syndrome. Investigators will recruit adolescents with TS aged 13-17 years of age presenting for routine clinical care. Questionnaires and semi-structured clinical interviews with participants and a parent/caregiver will be collected. Specifically, this battery of questionnaires and interviews will both screen for and quantify the extent of tics, stress, and mental health symptoms prevalent in TS, including anxiety, depression, obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

detailed_description.textblock:
Tourette syndrome (TS) is a multi-faceted neurodevelopmental disorder with wide-ranging impact on adolescent quality of life (QOL). Comorbid psychiatric and psychological factors exert greater influence on QOL than tics in TS, but the specific role of stress has been largely overlooked, despite the fact that this component of mental health has a profound effect on current and future QOL in those with chronic disease. Investigators propose a cross-sectional, observational pilot study to explore the prevalence of stress among adolescents with Tourette syndrome. The primary goal of this study is to collect sufficient data for hypothesis-generation and power analysis refinement in planning of a larger scale study.
Investigators will recruit adolescents with TS aged 13-17 years of age presenting for regular care at the Vanderbilt Pediatric Neurology Clinic. Questionnaires and semi-structured clinical interviews with participants and a parent/caregiver will be collected. Specifically, this battery of questionnaires and interviews will both screen for and quantify the extent of tics, stress, and mental health symptoms prevalent in TS, including anxiety, depression, obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The battery can be completed by the child and caregiver in parallel and is anticipated to take 50-60 minutes to complete. The study plans to enroll subjects over a 12-month time frame.

primary_outcome.measure: Youth Quality of Life Research Version (YQOL-R)
primary_outcome.description: Self-report quality of life scale comprised of 42 items with 10-point Likert scale (raw total score 0-420) and 15 additional items with open-ended and demographic questions. Higher scores indicate better overall quality of life.
Self-report self-esteem scale comprised of 10 items (total score range 10-40). Higher scores indicate higher self-esteem.

secondary_outcome.description: Self-report stress scale comprised of 10 items (total score range 0-40). Higher scores indicate greater perceived stress.

Caregiver-report scale comprised of 36 items (total score range 0-100) assessing impact of health condition(s) on family. Higher scores indicate better family functioning in context of health-related condition(s).

Caregiver-report scale comprised of 45 items assessing inattention, hyperactivity, and executive functioning of child. T-scores are generated, with higher scores indicating greater deviation from norms.
Self-report scale comprised of 41 items assessing inattention, hyperactivity, and executive functioning. T-scores are generated, with higher scores indicating greater deviation from norms.
Caregiver-report scale assessing executive functioning of child. T-scores are generated, with higher scores indicating greater deviation from norms.
Self-report scale assessing executive functioning. T-scores are generated, with higher scores indicating greater deviation from norms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Revised Children's Anxiety and Depression Scale (RCADS) - Parent Report
secondary_outcome.description: Caregiver-report scale comprised of 47 items assessing mood symptoms. T-scores are generated, with higher scores indicating greater deviation from norms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Revised Children's Anxiety and Depression Scale (RCADS) - Self-Report
secondary_outcome.description: Self-report scale comprised of 47 items assessing mood symptoms. T-scores are generated, with higher scores indicating greater deviation from norms.

Semi-structured clinician-administered interview assessing tic severity, with total tic score range of 0-50 and functional impairment scale range of 0-50. Higher scores indicate greater tic severity and functional impairment, respectively.

secondary_outcome.measure: School and Mental Health Services Inventory
secondary_outcome.description: Questionnaire assessing educational and functional status of child. No total score generated.

study_pop.textblock: Adolescents with Tourette syndrome aged 13-17 years of age presenting for routine clinical care, as well as the adolescents' caregivers.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adolescent age 13-17 years of age
- adolescent diagnosis of Tourette syndrome (TS)
- English-speaking adolescent and caregiver (as validated questionnaires are in English)
- adolescent and caregiver willingness and ability to complete relevant questionnaires
Exclusion Criteria:
- cognitive or attentional impairment precluding ability of adolescent or caregiver to complete self-report questionnaires
- adolescent diagnosis of genetic conditions besides TS and its known comorbidities
- adolescent with severe medical conditions unrelated to TS (e.g. uncontrolled seizures, prominent heart conditions)
- other variables that might influence ratings outside of the typical presentation of TS
